sense.name: a legal rule
sense.commentary: A legal document that regulates something.
sense.examples: Alabama has a law against kidnapping, among other activities. Senator McCain passed a law that reformed the funding of political campaigns. We have laws against that sort of thing! John broke about a dozen public-nuisance laws that night.

sense.name: the set of rules
sense.commentary: The abstract collection of rules, or a division thereof, that governs human society. Usually imposed by a ruling body.
sense.examples: Stealing music is against the law. Our city saw a breakdown of law and order. Civilization presupposes respect for the rule of law. The law forbids you to smoke in bars anymore. I don't know much about European contract law. Louis XIV ruled by divine law. Locke believed in a benign natural law, by which people can peacefully govern themselves.

sense.name: a scientific principle
sense.commentary: A generalization that describes a fact or recurring event in nature.
sense.examples: Newton's First Law of Motion was always my favorite. Only Bugs Bunny can defy the laws of thermodynamics.

sense.name: the legal profession or practice
sense.commentary: Refers narrowly to what you learn in law school and to what a lawyer practices.
sense.examples: He studied law for three years at Yale. John wanted to get into law after graduation. Bobby Donnell practiced law for six years.

sense.name: the police, in general
sense.commentary: Refers to the police, or any law-enforcement body, in a general way. Tends to have a long arm.
sense.examples: The law came looking for Billy the Kid. I don't want to get in trouble with the law! For years he'd been running from the law.
